content.description: Start climbing the left arÃªte from the bottom.
content.protection: Toprope using the westernmost pair of anchor bolts.

content.description: Offwidth just wider than stacked fists at the bottom, but not wide enough for a good kneebar. Getting up to the lip is the hardest part, then stay in the crack for continued groveling lessons, working your way back and up at the same time. A fun climb to learn technique on.
content.protection: Can be led with wide gear (5 inches on up). Can be toproped from the Knobby Wall anchor
content.location: Offwidth crack next to the Knobby Wall; the leftmost crack on Struggler Cliff.

content.description: Struggler is the off-width crack on the right side of the Struggler Cliff.  It is a very challenging crack but some features on the right wall facilitate the climbing.  If you don't use these features its 5.10+
content.protection:
Pro to 5 inches.

There is a old metal device to keep a toprope from rubbing the edge, but use it with caution. A tree above the slabby top section can be used for an anchor.

content.description: This short but fun route requires a bit of crack climbing technique.  The crack off the ground is offwidth as it's too big for fingers and too small for normal size hands.  A couple of strenuous layback moves get you to a stance with a bomber hand jam that gets you up and over to easier ground.  Easier lower angle climbing gets you to the top.
content.protection: Small to medium gear easily protect this crack climb.  There is a tree growing in the gully above whose branches can be used as anchors.

content.description:
This climb follows the obvious knobs to the right of of splitter up the 10 foot vertical face. Easier lower angle climbing gets you to the top.

Most variations of this line are 5.6 to 5.7, but as always, harder moves exist further outside the rope line.
content.protection: Toprope this climb from the tree as you start going down the gully to the climbs.  Cottrell's guide shows 2 bolts for an anchor, but they don't seem to be there.

content.description: No doubt many peoples' early rock climbs take place here. The name says it all, pick a path up the knobby face. The paths of least resistance are mostly 5.5 to 5.6, but some harder variations can be found.
content.protection: Two bolt anchor at top, toprope only.
content.location: Second anchors from the left (west) side of the Struggler Cliff, past the tree and offwidth of Surprise if scrambling to them on top.

content.description: Go to the left corner of the Struggler Cliff (5.5) or start in the dihedral just right of that (5.6),  for a crux off the ground. Slab walk and knob step up diagonally right to the leftmost anchor on this wall. Pick your grade of moves up to around 5.10 by using the arete left of the main line, or the less featured face right of it.
content.location: Left side of Struggler Cliff. Two bolt anchor is at the west end of the very wide flake of the cliff, past a buckeye tree and crack.

content.description: Big Surprise is the climb just right of the large offwidth crack called Surprise (5.8).  Climb up the steep face on thin holds to gain the lower angle rock above.  If you are 5' 10" or taller, a long reach up over the bulge to thin holds lessens the number of hand movements.  Otherwise it looks like you angle slightly right progressively moving hands higher on small holds.  A fun route but it's really 8' worth of climbing.
content.protection: This toprope climb uses the same tree anchor as Splitter which is the tree as you start going down the gully to the climbs.
